perturbation.original_text: "End User" means an end user customer of Distributor who is located in the Territory.
perturbation.changed_text: "End User" means any individual who, regardless of location, interacts with the Distributor App(s).
perturbation.explanation: The original definition limits 'End User' to those in the 'Territory.' The modified definition expands this to anyone interacting with the app, regardless of location. This broadens the scope beyond the defined territory, creating a contradiction.
perturbation.law_explanation: Contract law respects territorial restrictions. By changing the definition of 'End User' to include individuals outside the agreed territory, the contract's territorial limitations become ambiguous and potentially unenforceable.

perturbation.original_text: In this Agreement, "Confidential Information" means information disclosed by (or on behalf of) one party to the other party under this Agreement that is marked as confidential or, from its nature, content or the circumstances in which it is disclosed, might reasonably be supposed to be confidential, including the terms and conditions (including the Exhibits) of this Agreement. It does not include information that the recipient already knew, that becomes public through no fault of the recipient, that was independently developed by the recipient or that was lawfully given to the recipient by a third party.
perturbation.changed_text: In this Agreement, "Confidential Information" means all information exchanged between parties. It includes information the recipient already knew, information that becomes public, information independently developed by the recipient, and information lawfully given to the recipient by a third party.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition excludes certain types of information from being considered confidential. The modified definition includes these excluded types, broadening the scope of 'Confidential Information' to include nearly everything exchanged, directly conflicting with standard definitions and potentially hindering normal business operations.
perturbation.law_explanation: The Uniform Trade Secrets Act defines a trade secret, requiring it to be secret and have economic value. The modified definition includes information already known or public, directly contradicting the 'secrecy' requirement and therefore making enforcement as a trade secret questionable.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: Archives & Special Collections • Library • Penn Carey Law Skip to main content Home Library » Archives & Special Collections Archives & Special Collections The Archives and Special Collections Department of Biddle Law Library preserves, promotes, and provides access to the papers and records of two major legal organizations: The American Law Institute (ALI), and the National Bankruptcy Archives. The Department also cares for a collection of rare books, manuscripts, and archives from the University of Pennsylvania Carey Law School. Search Center Skip Sidebar Navigation Library Expand mobile section navigation Research Using The Library Faculty Services Archives & Special Collections About the Library News Library Map Library Hours Contact Us Collections The Archives of the American Law Institute (ALI) The ALI was established in 1923 by judges, lawyers, and law professors in an effort to promote the clarification, simplification, and scholarship of the law. The ALI Archives contains over 800 cubic feet of material documenting the administration, organization and work of the Institute, from early projects like the restatement of basic legal subjects to a collaboration with NCCUSL in developing and monitoring the Uniform Commercial Code. View more information about the ALI collections The National Bankruptcy Archives (NBA) In 2000, the Biddle Law Library and the American College of Bankruptcy collaborated to establish the National Bankruptcy Archives (NBA), a national repository of materials relating to the history of debtor-creditor relations, bankruptcy, and the reorganization of debt. The NBA currently contains over 1,000 linear feet of personal papers and institutional records. View more information about the NBA collections Explore the NBA Oral History collections Biddle Collections The Collections consist of manuscript collections, rare books, oral histories, and a select number of Penn Carey Law School’s records. The manuscript collections include the papers of George Wharton Pepper, Bernie Segal, William Draper Lewis, and David L. Bazelon. The Raymond F. Trent Collection consists of books, periodicals, articles, and audio tapes concerning the history of education and practice of Black lawyers in the United States. Some records relating to the operations of Penn Carey Law School are maintained by the University Archives . Please contact us for more information. View more information about the Biddle Law Library Collections Explore the collection of The Report the Law School’s yearbook Explore the Penn Carey Law Oral History Project collection Contact & Hours The Archives and Special Collections office is located on the fourth floor of Tanenbaum Hall. The mailing address is: University of Pennsylvania Carey Law School Biddle Law Library - Archives Department 3501 Sansom Street Philadelphia, PA 19104-3406 For questions about the Archives, the Rare Books Collection, or other special collections, please email the Archives Department at biddlearchives@law.upenn.edu . The Archives is open Tuesday-Friday, 10AM to 4PM. Appointments should be made 2 weeks in advance of the visit. Visitors will be asked to show identification. Policies Registration All researchers are asked to fill out our Researcher Registration Form. This form can be filled out prior to your visit or on the day of your arrival. Archives - Researcher Registration Form On-site Research Items in the Archives do not circulate. If you wish to come to the Archives to conduct research, you may do so free of charge. However, you must contact the department ahead of time to schedule an appointment. Appointments should be mad

perturbation.original_text: Google warrants that the Distribution Products will for a period of [ * ] from the date of their supply to Distributor be free from any defect which has a materially adverse effect on their use or operation.
perturbation.changed_text: Google warrants that the Distribution Products may function adequately at Google's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The original text contains a warranty for a specific period, implying a guarantee of quality. The modified text replaces this with a discretionary statement about adequate functionality, removing the guarantee and introducing ambiguity. The original text speaks of the products being free from any defect which has a materially adverse effect on their use or operation, while the changed text removes that language, instead saying the Google warrants that the distribution products may function adequately at Google's discretion.
perturbation.law_explanation: UCC § 2-313 addresses express warranties. By changing the warranty to a discretionary statement, Google could argue that no express warranty was created, undermining the buyer's protection under the UCC.
